MDR49006: Caribbean Hurricane Tomas
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Barbados, Saint Lucia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines:Â  The American Red Cross has committed $141,000 in cash and relief supplies to support the International Federationâs appeal for this multi-country response. Â The American Red Cross has an ongoing disaster preparedness program in Saint Lucia.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Haiti:Â  Since April, the American Red Cross has been working in Haitian camps and communities to prepare for the hurricane season. Â Project activities have included flood mitigation measures such as reinforcing embankments, creating drainage channels and establishing evacuations routes.Â  In addition, the Red Cross has trained resident volunteers to serve on camp-based disaster response teams, helping to create evacuation routes and establish early warning systems. Prior to the stormâs landfall, 53 of these teams were in the camps providing early warnings to residents.Â  After the storm, American Red Cross training teams for Disaster Risk Reduction conducted damage assessments from the storm in 24 camps.Â

Most recently, the American Red Cross provided assistance for the Mexican Red Cross after flooding in 2010.Â

Name: MDRWS001 (Rev): Samoa Earthquake and Tsunami
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Domestic Services
American Red Cross Disaster Services is responding in American Samoa, providing food, water and other supplies. A team of about 70 volunteers is also on the ground supplementing the local Red Cross volunteers. It is focusing on providing support services to assist the local chapter and its volunteers, and mass care and relief supplies to those affected.Â  To date, the American Red Cross has served more than 4,000 meals during the relief operation.
The American Red Cross is accepting disaster welfare inquiries for American Samoa only through the Safe and Well section of its website at www.redcross.org.

International Services
American Red Cross International Services is providing US $100,000 towards the International Federationâs appeal for Samoa.
The American Red Cross continues to monitor the situation and is prepared to mobilize support, including relief supplies, trained personnel or additional financial assistance if necessary.Â

Name: Haiti Earthquake
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Financials
Since the earthquake on January 12, the American Red Cross has spent or allocated more than $111 million to meet the most urgent needs of earthquake survivors in Haiti. Â Approximately 50 percent has funded emergency relief, including food and relief supplies; 39 percent has supported shelter; 6 percent has been dedicated for health, water and sanitation activities; and 5 percent has been allocated for livelihoods.
Â 
American Red Cross Total Contributions
Sector Consolidated Totals
Relief Supplies & Distribution Â·Â Â Â  American Red Cross has provided approximately 43% of the relief supplies for the Red Cross response aimed at 400,000 people. Items including hygiene kits, kitchen sets, buckets, water containers, blankets, sleeping mats and mosquito nets.
Â·Â Â Â  There is a Relief Emergency Response Unit on the ground to assess needs and distribute relief supplies in coordination with the global Red Cross response. This unit is on its fourth round of team members
Â·Â Â Â  $170,000 provided to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) for transportation of relief supplies to Haiti
Response & Recovery
Personnel		 Â·Â Â Â  19 American Red Cross response workers are in Haiti at this time in addition to 14 permanent staff on the ground; to date,165 have been deployed in support of the response.
Â·Â Â Â  There is a Relief Emergency Response Unit on the ground to assess needs and distribute relief supplies in coordination with the global Red Cross response.
Â·Â Â Â  American Red Cross has provided specialists working in the global Red Cross coordinated response supporting logistics, shelter, recovery, market analysis and communications.
Â·Â Â Â  An IT/Telecommunications Emergency Response Unit provided IT and communications networks for Red Cross during first two months of response.
Â·Â Â Â  During first two months of the response, 70 Red Cross volunteers served aboard the USNS Comfort as Creole translators.
Shelter Â·Â Â Â  $20 million to the global Red Cross response to support shelter expenses
Â·Â Â Â  $3.7 million to Habitat for Humanity for emergency shelter supplies
Â·Â Â Â  111,000 tarps provided for distribution in the global Red Cross response
Food, Water & Sanitation Â·Â Â Â  $10 million to the global Red Cross response to support emergency shelter, healthcare, water and sanitation services
Â·Â Â Â  $30 million to the UN World Food Programme (WFP) to feed one million people for one month
Â·Â Â Â  3 million heater meals for distribution by WFP
Â·Â Â Â  $600,000 to the ICRC to provide food at medical units on the ground
Â·Â Â Â  1.1 million water purification sachets donated by PSI
Health Â·Â Â Â  $2.4 million to the ICRC to underwrite Haiti operations, including the provision of healthcare, water and sanitation services
Â·Â Â Â  $829,000 to ICRC for medical tents and transportation of medical supplies
Â·Â Â Â  $375,000 for operational costs to support the coordinated vaccination campaign
Â·Â Â Â  American Red Cross Biomedical services has coordinated the shipment of more than 2,100 blood units to Haiti
Livelihoods & Supplemental Relief $4.6 million for microfinance and small relief grants through a partnership with Haitiâs largest microfinance institution, Fonkoze, to benefit 16,000 families (80,000 people) with support through:
Â·Â Â Â  Grants to 6,000 host families in rural communities who are sheltering those who fled the disaster
Â·Â Â Â  Grants and loans to 10,000 female-headed households to meet family needs and rebuild businesses
Disaster Preparedness & Risk Reduction
Â 		 Â·Â Â Â  In preparation for the hurricane and rainy seasons, the American Red Cross is conducting disaster preparedness activities in 25 settlements, such as identifying hazards, clearing ditches and establishing early earning systems to alert settlement residents in the event of flooding.
Family Tracing and Support Services Â·Â Â Â  Family Tracing services for Haitians to connect with relatives in the U.S.
Â·Â Â Â  450 satellite phones for ICRC Family Tracing services in Haiti
Â·Â Â Â  Chapters assisted more than 25,000 people who arrived in the U.S. following the earthquake with welcome services at airports, support for medical evacuees, family tracing and other services

Name: MDRHT010(Rev): Haiti Hurricane Sandy
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
The American Red Cross country office in Haiti provided direct support to camps in preparing for the storm by distributing tarps, coordinating with disaster risk reduction teams, and activating emergency response committees.

After the hurricane moved through the region the American Red Cross coordinated with the International Federation and Haitian Red Cross to support damage assessments.

The American Red Cross is contributing $100,000 to the International Federation1 emergency appeal and has provided $50,000 to restock relief supplies used in the immediate response.

The American Red Cross team continues to implement disaster preparedness activities in Haiti with a particular emphasis on providing additional support to response planning efforts for people living in vulnerable communities in Port au Prince. Â

Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross has a long history of providing and receiving support from the Mexican Red Cross.Â  The Mexican Red Cross national Disaster Operations Center was in fact built through support from the American Red Cross.

Name: Dominican Republic, Haiti Epidemic
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross has reached almost 116,000 people with information on cholera prevention, transmission and symptoms, as well as demonstrations on how to prepare oral rehydration solution and proper hand washing. Some 235 health promoters are going tent-to-tent with these messages in camps in Port-au-Prince, and an additional 130 volunteers are providing information in schools in the Northeast department.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  American Red Cross teams are also distributing soap, oral rehydration salts and water purification tablets in camps in Port-au-Prince, and have distributed some 253,000 relief items to over 110,000 people to date.
Â 
Additional American Red Cross Response Actions
Â·Â Â Â Â  $1.5 million to Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) for medical and hygiene supplies
Â·Â Â Â Â  $1.6 million for relief supplies including buckets, chlorine tablets and soap
Â·Â Â Â Â  $566,000 to the International Federation appeal to respond to the cholera epidemic in Haiti and the Dominican Republic
Â·Â Â Â Â  37,000 water containers and five large warehouse storage tents
Â·Â Â Â Â  5,000 cots for medical facilities
Â·Â Â Â Â  Chlorine for 75,000 gallons of water
Â·Â Â Â Â  790,000 sachets of oral rehydration salts
Â·Â Â Â Â  Funded three flights to transport medical supplies for Project Medishare and Partners in Health
Â·Â Â Â Â  Vehicle and generator for Haitian Red Cross
Â·Â Â Â Â  Additional support to expand our reach through other implementing partners is also planned.
Â 
Â

Name: Pakistan Monsoon Floods
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross has committed $6.5 million to the Pakistan response. This includes nearly Â $1 million in relief supplies from its two regional warehouses in Dubai and Kuala Lumpur, as well as financial contributions to the International Federation to support the costs of the response, particularly emergency shelter and the distribution of food and other household goods.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In addition, American Red Cross has provided two disaster specialists to support disaster management operations and coordinate relief distributions in collaboration with PRCS and Emergency Response Units on the ground.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross is monitoring the situation and stands ready to provide additional support as necessary.Â

ARC has also contributed 42,075 supplies (20,000 jerry cans, 22,075 mosquito nets, 2,075 tarps).

Name: Canadian Red Cross Recovery Direct Assistance Pillar, 2013 Alberta Floods
Response_Strategy_Comments__c: ARC will contribute $633,936 from AP 2688 in a bilateral agreement with the Canadian Red Cross to support the Red Cross Recovery Direct Assistance pillar. The goals of Red Cross Recovery Direct Assistance is to ensure families basic needs are met throughout the recovery period in order to help them address their gaps in financial capacity while working towards self-sustainability. Name: Plan of Action
Response_Strategy_Comments__c: The American Red Cross is contributing an additional $160,000 to the Mexican Red Cross to support ongoing Mexican Red Cross response efforts. This brings the total American Red Cross contribution to $630,000. The additional funds will be used to replenish and improve response equipment for the Mexican Red Cross to better and more effectively respond to emergencies in the future. Â The initial funds were used for the distribution of kitchen items, household cleaning supplies, and personal hygiene kits to 1,200 families.Â

MDRCO008: Colombia Floods
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross has recently provided an additional $120,000 to the Colombian Red Cross to support integrated mobile health clinics which will reach 3,000 people in the departments of BolÃ­var, CÃ³rdoba, Sucre, Guajira and Tolima with critically needed care. This is in addition to $80,000 for relief supplies and 6,000 insecticide-treated mosquito nets previously provided to the Red Cross response operation.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross also has two long-term programs in Colombia: a refugee assistance program in departments affected by conflict in Colombia and in the border province of Darien in Panama that provides health services and disaster preparedness education; and a community-based disaster preparedness program which trains people on a local level to respond to disasters.

Name: MDRTR002: Turkey Earthquake
Response_Strategy_Comments__c:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The American Red Cross has committed an additional $88,000 to the International Federation appeal in support of the Turkish Red Crescent response, bringing the total to date to $897,000 to support relief and emergency shelter for those in need.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Previously, the American Red Cross has assisted the Turkish Red Crescent following major earthquakes in 1999 and 2001, providing support for both immediate response and long term recovery. The American Red Cross also assisted the Turkish Red Crescent in establishing a national headquarters-based disaster operations center, expanding their capacity to respond.Â
